Award.AwardTitle: SusChem: Sustainable Chemicals Production Using Solid Polymer Electrolyte Reactors

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Principal Investigator: Peter N. Pintauro
Number: 1437384

Nontechnical Description

To address concerns related to carbon dioxide emissions and dependence on foreign sources of fossil fuels, the chemical process industry is working to transition its manufacturing methods towards more sustainable raw materials and production schemes. A potentially transformational strategy to improve the environmental and energy sustainability of organic chemical manufacturing would involve the replacement of thermally driven reactions with processes that are driven directly by electricity obtained from renewable resources. A prime example is the reaction of organic chemicals with hydrogen gas to make a variety of new chemicals, a process called hydrogenation, which accounts for up to 20% of all reaction steps in a typical chemical process. Hydrogen gas is typically obtained from the reforming of natural gas, which is an energy-intensive and complicated process requiring fossil fuels. New systems based on electrochemistry offer a sustainable alterative. The overall goal of this study is to develop an electrochemical reactor to carry out the hydrogenation of organic chemicals using electricity, water, and the organic chemical feedstock as the only inputs. In particular, solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) reactors which promote electrochemical reactions are a potentially efficient platform for this purpose. These reactors internally generate hydrogen which feeds the hydrogenation reaction that is occurring at the cathode of the reactor system. The mild temperatures and high hydrogen concentrations at the cathode can promote the production of a variety of commercially relevant hydrogenated organic products. The innovative aspects of the project include the use of electricity, preferably from renewable resources, to drive the chemical reactions under mild conditions of temperature and pressure, the development of novel catalytic cathodes to improve product selectivity, and the use of water as the source of hydrogen. The project will train graduate students in multi-disciplinary science and engineering technologies, including electrochemistry, chemical engineering, and chemical catalysis.

Technical Description

The overall goal of this study is to develop an electrochemical reactor to carry out the hydrogenation of organic chemicals using electricity, water, and the organic chemical feedstock as the only inputs. The availability of low-cost, renewable electricity could drive a transformation in the chemicals processing industry via a significant expansion in the commercial use of electrochemical reactors that use solid polymer electrolytes (SPE) for driving organic hydrogenation reactions. Expanded use and improved designs for such reactors would benefit from a better understanding of the inter-relationships between cathode composition, reactor operating parameters, product yields, and current efficiencies. Towards this end, this project will investigate the use of new catalytic materials and hybrid electrochemical/chemical mixed catalytic systems as the cathode electrode in SPE reactors, and study the selective hydrogenation of multifunctional organic substrates. Experiments will be performed to correlate reactor operating conditions and feed composition to power consumption and products yield. The mechanistic details of electrochemical organic substrate hydrogenation and hydrogen generation on catalytic cathodes will be elucidated through analysis of kinetic data from batch slurry reactor experiments. The project will train graduate students in multi-disciplinary science and engineering technologies, including electrochemistry, chemical engineering, and chemical catalysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SusChem: Sustainable Chemicals Production Using Solid Polymer Electrolyte Reactors

     This project had three basic outcomes: (1) physical products: Membrane-Electrode-Assemblies (MEAs) were fabricated with electrically conductive metal catalysts powders (e.g., Pd-black) and with a mixture of non-conductive supported metal catalyst particles (e.g., Pd/Al2O3) and carbon powder. These MEAs were used in an electrochemical reactor to hydrogenate various organic compounds at moderate temperature and atmospheric pressure, (2) general knowledge: we showed for the first time that hydrogen made electrochemically on a metal surface can spill over onto a non-conductive supported metal catalyst and then react with an organic feedstock, and (3) student training: graduate students were trained in a unique combination of subject areas, i.e., catalyst development, electrochemistry, fuel cells, and organic chemistry.  A fuel cell was operated in reverse to generate hydrogen on a catalyst surface for organic species hydrogenation. Such a reactor represents an entirely new way of synthesizing hydrogenated organic chemicals, using water as the source of hydrogen, where the reactor operates at moderate temperatures and pressures.

     The U.S. chemical industry consumes more than 5 quadrillion BTUs annually or nearly 25% of all energy used for manufacturing. Most of this energy is derived from fossil fuels combustion. To address concerns related to CO2 emissions and our dependence on foreign fossil fuels, the National Research Council’s Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology defined grand challenges and research objectives to transition the chemicals industry towards more sustainable products, processes, and systems. A transformational strategy to improve the environmental and energy sustainabilities of chemicals production would involve the replacement of thermally driven processes with processes that are driven directly by renewable electrical energy. Solid Polymer Electrolyte (SPE) based electrochemical reactors could be used for this purpose. These types of reactors, which are similar to hydrogen/air fuel cells, utilize H2O or H2 gas as the source of hydrogen, with electrochemical hydrogen generation and chemical catalytic organic feed hydrogenation occurring within the cathode.  The mild temperatures and high hydrogen concentrations at the cathode, with the possible coupling of electrochemical and chemical cathode catalysts, will result in the efficient and sustainable production of hydrogenated organic products. Thus, the results of this project have advanced the concept of sustainable manufacturing processes, as related to the petrochemical industry.

The project coupled conventional chemical catalysis with electrochemistry. Such a merger of two distinctly different fields of study is unique and led to interesting and unanticipated results. The project has established a stronger scientific basis for considering the use of SPE reactors for organic synthesis, where, low-cost, renewable electricity is used for chemical synthesis/processing rather than heat and pressure and where clean and “green” water is used as the source of hydrogen for organic chemical hydrogenation. This project has set the groundwork for additional studies on electrochemical hydrogenation reactions, with improvements in reaction selectivity and the use of hybrid multi-catalyst cathodes.  Such results represent important innovations towards improving the sustainability of chemicals production via hybrid chemical-electrochemical reaction schemes.

     The broader impacts of the project outcomes are significant and noteworthy.  One refereed journal paper is in preparation.  Multiple conference presentations on the project results have generated considerable interest in organic electrochemical synthesis. The project trained two female graduate students in multi-disciplinary science and engineering technologies.  These students acquired a unique set of skills (electrochemistry, chemical engineering, reactor design and operation, and catalysis). One student has graduated with a M.S. degree while another is continuing to pursue here PhD with a focus on new electrode designs for hydrogen/air fuel cells. Students also received training in communications skills via technical paper writing and the presentation of research results at engineering conferences. Whereas the focus of the project was to hydrogenate selected model organic compounds, the general reactor design work has applications to a wide range of electrochemical synthesis reactions, including CO2 and NO2 reduction.
